CommonFields.Title: Compatibilizing Bulk Polymer Blends by Using Organoclays
Author: Si, Mayu
Araki, Tohru
Ade, Harald
Kilcoyne, A. L. D.
Fisher, Robert
Sokolov, Jonathan C.
Rafailovich, Miriam H.
CommonFields.Location: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, New York 11794-2275; Department of Physics, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, North Carolina 27695; Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California 94720-8225; and Hebrew Academy of Nassau County High School, Uniondale, New York 11553

ParticleSurfaceTreatment.ChemicalName: N,N-dimethyl dihydrogenated tallow quaternary ammonium chloride

Mixing.Description: The materials were prepared by melt mixing in a C.W. Brabender, a total of 50 g, divided into different weight ratios of polymers and organoclays. To obtain thorough mixing, polymers were first inserted into the chamber and mixed at 20 rpm for 1 min.
After initial mixing, the clay was added and mixed at 100 rpm for 10 min.

Transmission_Electron_Microscopy.Description: Morphology of the sample was observed using a JEOL JEM1200ex transmission electron microscope (TEM) at 60 kV.

Dynamic_Mechanical_Analysis.Description: Dynamic mechanical properties were performed using a Mettler Toledo DMA/SDTA861e dynamic mechanical analyzer with a single cantilever bend mode.

Differential_Scanning_Calorimetry.Description: Thermal properties were studied using a Mettler Toledo DSC 821e differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) under a nitrogen atmosphere. Samples of about 10 mg were heated at a rate of 10°C/min from 25 to 200°C.

SampleSize.description: dynamic mechanical analysis sample size: 10mm x 10mm
